title: Nordic Power Prices Lifted By German And Carbon Markets
text:
Rising German and carbon prices pushed Nordic power rates up, but wetter weather and strong hydro reserves are keeping gains in check.
14 minutes ago • 2 mins
Join the newsletter that everyone in finance secretly reads. 1M+ subscribers, 100% free.
What’s going on here?
Nordic power prices edged higher this week, lifted by climbing German electricity and carbon markets, but strong hydro reserves and plenty of wet weather are stopping costs from spiraling.
What does this mean?
The Nordic power market is feeling the tug-of-war between rising European prices and robust local supply. On the one hand, pricier German electricity and higher EU carbon costs drove up Nordic futures contracts by 1.6%. But with hydro reservoirs sitting about 3 terawatt hours above average for the next two weeks—and forecasts calling for more rain and mild weather—there’s plenty of supply to soften price pressures. Even as futures ticked up, the physical system price for next-day delivery dropped over 40%, showing just how quickly actual market sentiment can shift as supply builds. LSEG analysts expect the wet conditions to last into November, likely keeping hydro availability strong and tempering volatility for now.
Why should I care?
For markets: Energy prices in flux.
This week’s 1.6% rise in Nordic futures lines up with gains across European power and carbon markets, reflecting cross-border influences on regional electricity costs. Yet, the Nordics saw next-day delivery prices plunge by 40%, underlining how quickly prices can adjust when hydro supply is flush. Gas prices in the UK and Netherlands also edged up, showing just how interconnected energy markets have become—what happens in one country or sector now ripples through the rest.
The bigger picture: Hydro puts a cap on volatility.
The Nordics’ hydro surplus—hovering well above seasonal averages—acts as a cushion against Europe’s broader upswing in power and carbon costs, showing the resilience of renewables in shaping local markets. The EU’s carbon trading scheme keeps fossil fuel costs climbing, nudging more regions toward hydro and other renewables. If the current wet weather holds, the region’s dependence on water power could keep price swings in check, even as Europe’s energy landscape stays volatile.
